derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English : the sense have a common boundary’ from Anglo-Latin abuttare, from a- (from Latin ad 'to, at') + Old French but 'end'; the sense 'lean upon' (late 16th cent.) from Old French abouter, from a- (from Latin ad 'to, at') + bouter 'strike, butt', of Germanic origin

entry.def: When land or a building abuts something or abuts on something, it is next to it.

example.ex: One edge of the garden abutted on an old entrance to the mine...
example.tran: 花园的一侧紧靠着矿井的旧入口。

example.ex: He was born in 1768 in the house abutting our hotel.
example.tran: 他于1768年出生于我们旅馆旁边的一幢房子里。

means.word_mean: 1. lie adjacent to another or share a boundary;
